2.title: The air pressure that acts on anything immersed in it:-

variants.a: Is also known as Static Pressure.
variants.b: Is also known as Dynamic Pressure.
variants.c: Is greater at altitude than at sea level.
variants.d: Is also known as Total Pressure.

3.title: If, on a given day, the actual outside air temperature at 4000 ft is 23°C, what is the approximate difference between the actual and ISA temperature?

variants.a: In air will reduce its density.
variants.b: In air will increase its density.
variants.c: In the atmosphere will increase the power output of a piston engine.
variants.d: In the atmosphere will increase the amount of lift generated by an aircraft.

5.title: When considering the changes in density of the air with altitude, which of the following four options is correct?

variants.a: The reduction in pressure with increasing altitude causes density to reduce.
variants.b: The temperature increase with increasing altitude causes density to increase.
variants.c: The temperature reduction with increasing altitude causes density to increase.
variants.d: The increase in pressure with increasing altitude causes density to reduce.

6.title: The respective percentages of the four most abundant gases that make up the atmosphere are?

7.title: The properties of the Earth s atmosphere which influence the performance of aircraft are:

variants.a: Its water vapour content, temperature, pressure and density.
variants.c: Its oxygen content pressure, and water vapour content
variants.d: Its nitrogen content, oxygen content, temperature and pressure.

8.title: Assuming that the pressure at sea level is ISA, but the temperature is 10°C higher than ISA, the density will be:

variants.c: Is measured in Pascals per square inch.

10.title: A piston engine aircraft flies in that layer of the atmosphere called:

12.title: The unit of force is the:

13.title: The dynamic pressure exerted on an aircraft's frontal surface is equal to:

variants.a: Half the density times the true airspeed squared.
variants.c: Half the true airspeed times the density squared.
variants.d: Half the density times the indicated airspeed squared.

14.title: Relative airflow is ___and_____the movement of the aircraft.

variants.c: Perpendicular to / in the same direction as.
variants.d: Parallel to / in the same direction as.

15.title: The symbol for dynamic pressure is:

16.title: The air flow over the wing's upper surface in straight and level flight, when compared with the airflow that is unaffected by the wing, will have:

17.title: Which of the four answer options most correctly completes the sentence? Increasing speed also increases lift because:

variants.a: The increased speed of the air passing over an aerofoil's upper surface decreases the static pressure above the wing, thus creating a greater pressure differential across the upper and lower surface.
variants.b: Lift is directly proportional to velocity.
variants.c: The increased velocity of the relative wind overcomes the increased drag.

18.title: An aircraft has a nose down pitching moment due to the lift/weight couple and a nose up pitching moment due to the thrust/drag couple. When power is increased:

variants.c: The couples both increase in magnitude but remain balanced.
variants.d: The couples both decrease in magnitude but remain balanced.

19.title: Considering the forces acting upon an aeroplane, at constant airspeed, which statement is correct?

variants.a: Weight always acts vertically downwards towards the centre of the Earth.
variants.b: Lift acts perpendicular to the chord line and must always be greater than weight
variants.c: Thrust acts parallel to the relative airflow and is greater than drag.
variants.d: The lift force generated by the wings always acts in the opposite direction to the aircraft's weight.

20.title: In straight and level flight, the free stream airflow pressure, compared to that flowing under the wing, is:

21.title: If the cross sectional area of an airflow is mechanically reduced:

variants.a: The mass flow remains constant and the velocity of the airflow increases.
variants.b: The velocity of the airflow remains constant and the mass flow increases.
variants.c: The mass flow remains constant and the static pressure increases.
variants.d: The velocity of the airflow remains constant and the kinetic energy increases.

variants.a: The amount by which the pressure rises at a point where a moving airflow is brought completely to rest.
variants.b: The total pressure at a point where a moving airflow is brought completely to rest.
variants.c: The pressure due to the mass of air pressing down on the air beneath.
variants.d: The pressure change caused by heating when a moving airflow is brought completely to rest.

23.title:
When considering air: 
1 - Air has mass 
2 - Air is not compressible 
3 - Air is able to flow or change its shape when subject to even small pressures 
4 - The viscosity of air is very high 
5 - Moving air has kinetic energy 
The correct combination of all true statements is:

25.title: An aircraft's mass is a result of:

variants.d: Total pressure divided by static pressure.

27.title: If the velocity of an air mass is increased:

variants.a: The kinetic energy will increase, the dynamic pressure will increase and the static pressure will decrease.
variants.b: The dynamic pressure will decrease and the static pressure will increase.
variants.c: The static pressure will remain constant and the kinetic energy will increase.
variants.d: The mass flow will stay constant, the dynamic pressure will decrease and the static pressure will increase.
Turbulent flow at low speeds only.

29.title: What must be the relationship between the forces acting on an aircraft in flight, for that aircraft to be in a state of equilibrium?

variants.a: Lift must equal weight, and thrust must equal drag.
variants.b: Lift must equal drag, and thrust must equal weight
variants.c: Lift must equal thrust plus drag.
variants.d: Lift must equal thrust, and weight must equal drag.

30.title: The smooth flow of air, where each molecule follows the path of the preceding molecule, is a definition of:

31.title: In sub-sonic airflow, as air passes through a venturi, the mass flow_____, the velocity _____and the static pressure_____.

variants.a: Remains constant / increases then decreases / decreases then increases.
variants.b: a) Decreases then increases / remains constant / increases then decreases.
variants.c: Remains constant / increases then decreases / increases then decreases.
variants.d: Decreases then increases / increases then decreases / increases then decreases.

33.title: Dynamic Pressure may be expressed by the formula:

variants.c: Is dependant on the weight of the aircraft?

35.title: As Indicated Air Speed (IAS) is reduced, in order to maintain altitude, the pilot must:

variants.a: Increase the angle of attack to maintain the correct lift force.
variants.b: Decrease the angle of attack to reduce the drag.
variants.c: Deploy the speed brakes to increase drag.

36.title: That portion of the aircraft's total drag created by the production of lift is called:

variants.a: Induced drag, which is greatly affected by changes in airspeed.
variants.b: Parasite drag, which is greatly affected by changes in airspeed.
variants.c: Induced drag, which is not affected by changes in airspeed.
variants.d: Parasite drag, which is inversely proportional to the square of the airspeed.

37.title: By changing the Angle of Attack of a wing, the pilot can control the aeroplane's:

variants.b: Lift and airspeed, but not drag.
variants.d: Lift and drag, but not airspeed.

38.title: Resistance, or skin friction, due to the viscosity of the air as it passes along the surface of a wing, is a type of:

39.title: If the Indicated Air Speed of an aircraft is increased from 50 kts to 100 kts, parasite drag will be:

41.title: A positively cambered aerofoil starts to produce lift at an angle of attack of approximately:

42.title: On an aerofoil section, the force of lift acts perpendicular to, and the force of drag acts parallel to, the:

43.title: As airspeed increases induced drag_____, parasite drag_____and total drag

44.title: If in level flight the airspeed decreases below that for maximum Lift/Drag, the effect will be that:

variants.a: Drag increases because of increased induced drag.
variants.b: Drag decreases because of lower induced drag.
variants.c: Drag increases because of increased parasite drag.
variants.d: Drag decreases because of lower parasite drag.

45.title: The angle of attack is the angle between the:

variants.a: Chord line and the relative airflow.
variants.b: Camber line and free stream flow.
variants.c: Chord line and the longitudinal axis of the aeroplane.
variants.d: Chord line and the horizontal plane.

46.title: The maximum value of the coefficient of lift is found at an angle of attack of approximately:

47.title: At a constant angle of attack, a decrease in the airspeed of an aircraft will result in:

variants.a: A decrease in lift and drag.
variants.b: An increase in lift and a decrease in drag.
variants.c: An increase in drag and a decrease in lift.
variants.d: Possible increases or decreases in lift or drag, depending on the actual speed.

48.title: If the Angle of Attack and other factors remain constant, and the airspeed is doubled, lift will be:

variants.c: One quarter of what it was.

variants.a: The aerodynamic force which acts at 90° to the relative airflow.
variants.b: The aerodynamic force which acts perpendicular to the chord line of the aerofoil.
variants.c: The aerodynamic force that results from the pressure differentials about an aerofoil.
variants.d: The aerodynamic force which acts perpendicular to the upper surface of the aerofoil.

50.title: Which of the answer options most correctly completes the sentence? The amount of lift a wing produces is directly proportional to:-

variants.b: The dynamic pressure minus the static pressure.
variants.c: The square root of the velocity of the air flowing over it.

51.title: The maximum value of the Coefficient of Lift is found:

variants.a: At the stalling angle of attack.

52.title: At a given Indicated Air Speed, what effect will an increase in air density have on lift and drag?

variants.a: Lift and drag will remain the same.
variants.b: Lift will increase but drag will decrease.

53.title: An aerofoil section is designed to produce lift resulting from a difference in the:

variants.a: Higher air pressure below the surface and lower air pressure above the surface.
variants.b: Negative air pressure below and a vacuum above the surface.
variants.c: Vacuum below the surface and greater air pressure above the surface.
variants.d: Higher air pressure at the leading edge than at the trailing edge.

54.title: Full flaps should be selected when:

55.title: A wing which is inclined downwards from root to tip is said to have:

56.title: When the C of G is close to the forward limit:

variants.a: Very high stick forces are required to pitch because the aircraft is very stable.
variants.b: Very small forces are required on the control column to produce pitch.
variants.d: Stick forces are the same as for an aft C of G.

57.title: Following a lateral disturbance, an aircraft with Dutch roll instability will:

variants.a: Develop simultaneous oscillations in roll and yaw.

58.title: An aeroplane which is inherently stable will:

variants.a: Have a built-in tendency to return to its original state following the removal of any disturbing force.

59.title: After a disturbance in pitch, an aircraft oscillates in pitch with increasing amplitude. It is:

60.title: If a disturbing force causes an aircraft to roll:

variants.a: Wing dihedral will cause a rolling moment which tends to correct the sideslip.
variants.b: The fin will cause a yawing moment which reduces the sideslip.
variants.c: Wing dihedral will cause a yawing moment which tends to correct the sideslip.
variants.d: Wing dihedral will cause a nose up pitching moment

61.title: If the wing Aerodynamic Centre is forward of the C of G:

variants.a: Changes in lift produce a wing pitching moment which acts to increase the change of lift.
variants.b: Changes in lift produce a wing pitching moment which acts to reduce the change of lift.
variants.c: Changes in lift give no change in wing pitching moment.
variants.d: When the aircraft sideslips, the CofG causes the nose to turn into the sideslip thus applying a restoring moment.

62.title: By design, the Centre of Pressure on a particular aircraft remains behind the aircraft's C of G. If the aircraft is longitudinally stable and is displaced in pitch, nose down, by turbulence:

variants.a: The tailplane will generate a downward force.
variants.b: The tailplane will generate an upward force.
variants.c: Neither an upward nor a downward force will be generated by the tailplane, as the aircraft will already be in equilibrium.
variants.d: The aircraft will maintain its nose-down attitude.

63.title: Wing dihedral produces a stabilising rolling moment by causing an increase in lift:

variants.a: On the lower wing when the aircraft is sideslipping.
variants.b: On the up-going wing when the aircraft rolls.
variants.c: On the up-going wing when the aircraft is sideslipping.
variants.d: On the lower wing whenever the aircraft is in a banked attitude.

64.title: When an aircraft is disturbed from its established flight path by, for example, turbulence, it is said to have positive stability if it subsequently:

variants.a: Re-establishes its original flight path without any input from the pilot.
variants.b: Remains on the new flight path.
variants.c: Becomes further displaced from its original flight path.
variants.d: Continues to pitch in the disturbed direction until the displacement is resisted by opposing control forces.

65.title: Loading an aircraft so that the C of G exceeds the aft limits could result in:

variants.a: Loss of longitudinal stability and the nose pitching up at slow speeds.
variants.b: Excessive upward force on the tail, and the nose pitching down.

66.title: Which of the following four options describes the consequence of taking off with the manufacturer's recommended take-off flap setting selected?

variants.a: A decrease in the length of the take-off run compared to a non-flap take-off.
variants.b: An increase in the length of the take-off run compared to a non-flap take-off.
variants.d: Easier avoidance of obstacles at the end of a runway.

67.title: With the flaps lowered, the stalling speed will:

variants.c: Increase, but occur at a higher angle of attack.

68.title: When an aircraft is disturbed from its trimmed attitude by, for example, turbulence, it is said to have neutral stability if it subsequently:

variants.b: Oscillates about its original attitude before settling back to that original attitude.
variants.d: Continues to move in the disturbed direction until the displacement is resisted by opposing control forces.

69.title: If the Centre of Gravity (C of G) of an aircraft is found to be within limits for take-off:

variants.a: The CofG limits for landing must be checked, allowing for planned fuel consumption.
variants.b: The CofG will always be within limits for landing.
variants.c: The CofG will not change during the flight.
variants.d: The flight crew will always be certain of being able to adjust the C of G during flight in order to keep it within acceptable limits for landing.

70.title: With a forward Centre of Gravity, an aircraft will have:

72.title: An aft Centre of Gravity will give:

73.title: The tendency of an aircraft to develop forces which restore it to its original flight situation, when disturbed from a condition of steady flight, is known as:

variants.a: Is increased if the keel surface behind the CofG is increased.
variants.b: Is given by the lateral dihedral.
variants.d: Is greater if the wing has no sweepback.

75.title: The maximum gliding distance from 6000 feet, for an aircraft in clean configuration, with a lift/drag ratio of 8:1, is approximately 8 nautical miles. If flaps are deployed:

variants.a: The maximum gliding distance will be less.
variants.b: The maximum gliding distance will increase.
variants.c: Lift/Drag ratio will be unaffected but will be achieved at a lower airspeed.
variants.d: The maximum gliding distance will be unaffected.

76.title: A pilot lowers the flaps while keeping the airspeed constant. In order to maintain level flight, the angle of attack:

variants.c: Must be kept constant but power must be increased.
variants.d: Must be kept constant and power required will be constant.

77.title: Movement of the aircraft about its normal (vertical) axis is known as:-

78.title: An aircraft wing is constructed with positive dihedral in order to give:

variants.a: Lateral stability about the longitudinal axis.
variants.b: Longitudinal stability about the lateral axis.
variants.c: Lateral stability about the normal axis.
variants.d: Directional stability about the normal axis.

79.title: An aircraft is disturbed from its path by a gust of wind. Neutral stability is when, without pilot intervention, it:

variants.b: Returns to its original path without overshooting.
variants.c: Returns to its original path after overshooting.
variants.d: Continues to move away from the original path.

80.title: When flaps are lowered the stalling angle of attack of the wing:

variants.b: Remains the same, but Clmax increases.
variants.d: Decreases, but Clmax remains the same.

81.title: A high wing configuration with no dihedral, compared to a low wing configuration with no dihedral, will provide:

variants.c: The same degree of longitudinal stability as any other configuration because dihedral gives longitudinal stability.

82.title: An aircraft is disturbed from its flight path by a gust of wind. If it tends to return to its original flight path without pilot intervention, the aircraft is said to possess:

83.title: Wing leading-edge devices such as slots, designed to allow flight at higher angles of attack, do so by:

variants.a: Re-energising the airflow over the top of the wing, delaying separation.
variants.b: Providing an extra lifting surface and hence increase the lift available.
variants.c: Changing the shape and hence the lift characteristics of the wing.
variants.d: Decreasing lift and hence induced drag.

84.title: The surface that gives an aircraft directional stability is:

85.title: If a landing is to be made without flaps the landing speed must be:

variants.c: The same as for a landing with flaps.
variants.d: The same as for a landing with flaps but with a steeper approach.

86.title: The maximum speed at which the aircraft can be flown with flaps extended is called:

88.title: The lateral axis of an aircraft is a line which:

variants.a: Passes through the Centre of Gravity, parallel to a line through the wing tips.
variants.c: Passes through the Centre of Pressure, at right angles to the direction of the airflow.
variants.d: Passes through the quarter-chord point of the wing root at right angles to the longitudinal axis.

89.title: Lowering the flaps during a landing approach:

variants.a: Increases the angle of descent without increasing the airspeed.
variants.b: Permits approaches at a higher indicated airspeed.
variants.c: Decreases the angle of descent without increasing power.

90.title: During a manoeuvre, the ailerons are deflected and returned to neutral when the aircraft has attained a small angle of bank. If the aircraft then returns to a wings-level attitude without further control movement, it is:

91.title: The purpose of an anti-balance tab is to:

variants.a: Ensure that the pilot's physical control load increases with increase of control surface deflection.
variants.c: Reduce the load required to move the controls at all speeds.
variants.d: Reduce the load required to move the controls at high speeds only.

92.title: The phenomenon of flutter is described as:

variants.a: Oscillatory motion of part or parts of the aircraft relative to the remainder of the structure.
variants.b: Rapid oscillatory motion involving only rotation of the control surfaces, associated with the shock waves produced around the control surfaces.
variants.c: Rapid movement of the airframe caused by vibration from the engines.
variants.d: Reversal of the ailerons caused by wing torsional flexibility.

93.title: An aileron could be balanced aerodynamically by:

variants.a: Having the control hinge set back behind the control surface leading edge.
variants.b: Making the up aileron move through a larger angle than the down aileron.
variants.c: Attaching a weight to the control surface forward of the hinge.
variants.d: Having springs in the control circuit to assist movement

94.title: When the control column is pushed forward, a balance tab on the elevator:

variants.a: Will move up relative to the control surface.
variants.b: Will move down relative to the control surface.
variants.c: Will only move if the trim wheel is operated.

95.title: The purpose of a differential ailerons is to:

variants.a: Reduce the opposite yawing moment when making a turn.
variants.b: Increase the yawing moment which opposes a turn.
variants.c: Induce a pitching moment to prevent the nose from dropping in the turn.

97.title: On an aircraft with a simple trim tab incorporated into a control surface, when the surface is moved, the tab remains in the same position relative to the:

99.title: The primary and secondary effects of applying the left rudder alone are:

100.title: When displacing the ailerons from the neutral position:

variants.a: The down-going aileron causes an increase in induced drag.
variants.b: The up-going aileron causes an increase in induced drag.
variants.c: Induced drag remains the same; the up-going aileron causes a smaller increase in profile drag than the down-going aileron.
variants.d: Both cause an increase in induced drag.

101.title: An aircraft's rudder is fitted with a balance tab. Movement of the rudder bar to the right, to yaw the aircraft to the right, will move the balance tab to the:

variants.a: Left and the rudder to the right.
variants.b: Right and the rudder to the left.
variants.c: Right and the rudder to the right.
variants.d: Left and the rudder to the left.

102.title: An aircraft has a tendency to fly right wing low with hands off. It is trimmed with a tab the left aileron. The trim tab will:

variants.a: Move down causing the left aileron to move up, and right aileron to move down.
variants.b: Move up, causing the left aileron to move up and right aileron to move down.
variants.c: Move down, causing the left aileron to move up, right aileron remains neutral.
variants.d: Move up causing the left wing to move down, ailerons remain neutral.

variants.a: Lateral control about the longitudinal axis.
variants.b: Lateral control about the lateral axis.
variants.c: Longitudinal control about the lateral axis.
variants.d: Directional control about the normal axis.

104.title: Following re-trimming for straight and level flight, in an aircraft with a C of G near its forward limit, and an elevator fitted with a conventional trim-tab:

variants.a: Nose-up pitch authority will be reduced.
variants.b: Nose-down pitch authority will be reduced.

105.title: Controls are mass balanced in order to:

variants.b: Aerodynamical I y assist the pilot in moving the controls.
variants.c: Provide equal control forces on all three controls.
variants.d: Return the control surface to neutral when the controls are released.

107.title: The purpose of a spring-bias trim system is:

variants.a: To reduce to zero the effort required by the pilot to counter stick force, after making a control movement.
variants.b: To maintain a constant tension in the trim tab system.
variants.c: To increase the feel in the control system.
variants.d: To compensate for temperature changes in cable tension.

108.title: A control surface may have a mass balance fitted to it, in order to:

variants.a: Help prevent a rapid and uncontrolled oscillation which is called "flutter".
variants.c: Lighten the forces needed to control the surface.

109.title: A control surface may be mass balanced by:

variants.a: Attaching a weight acting forward of the hinge line.
variants.d: Attaching weight acting aft of the hinge line.

variants.a: Can be adjusted on the ground after a test flight to make wings-level flight easier.
variants.d: Can be adjusted on the ground after a test flight to make turning easier.

111.title: Which flying control surface(s) give(s) longitudinal control?

112.title: The purpose of a trim tab is:

variants.a: To zero the load on the pilots controls in the flight attitude required.
variants.b: To assist the pilot in initiating movement of the controls.
variants.c: To provide feel to the controls at high speed.
variants.d: To increase the effectiveness of the controls.

variants.a: The normal axis controlled by the rudder.
variants.b: The lateral axis controlled by the rudder.
variants.c: The longitudinal axis controlled by the ailerons.
variants.d: The normal axis controlled by the elevator.

114.title: If the control column is moved forward and to the left:

variants.a: The left aileron moves up, right aileron moves down, elevator moves down.
variants.b: The left aileron moves up, right aileron moves down, elevator moves up.
variants.c: The left aileron moves down, right aileron moves up, elevator moves down.
variants.d: The left aileron moves down, right aileron moves up, elevator moves up.

115.title: If the control column is moved to the right, a balance tab on the left aileron should:

variants.a: Move up relative to the aileron.
variants.b: Move down relative to the aileron.
variants.c: Not move unless the aileron trim wheel is turned.

116.title: 'Differential Ailerons' are a design feature that helps to counteract:

117.title: If the angle of attack is increased above the stalling angle:

variants.a: Lift will decrease and drag will increase.
variants.b: Lift and drag will both decrease.
variants.c: Lift will increase and drag will decrease.
variants.d: Lift and drag will both increase.

118.title: If the Angle of Attack is increased beyond the Critical Angle of Attack, the wing will no longer produce sufficient lift to support the weight of the aircraft:

variants.a: Regardless of airspeed or pitch attitude.
variants.b: Unless the airspeed is greater than the normal stall speed.
variants.c: Unless the pitch attitude is on or below the natural horizon.
variants.d: In which case, the control column should be pulled-back immediately.

variants.a: The critical angle of attack is exceeded.
variants.b: The indicated airspeed is too low.
variants.d: It is subjected to unusually high 'G' forces.

124.title: The angle of attack at which an aeroplane stalls:

variants.a: Will remain constant, regardless of gross weight.
variants.b: Will be smaller flying downwind than when flying upwind.
variants.c: Is dependent upon the speed of the airflow over the wing.
variants.d: Is a function of speed and density altitude.

125.title: When the aircraft is in a spin, the direction of spin is most reliably found by reference to which of the following indications?

126.title: The reason for washout being designed into an aircraft wing is to:-

variants.a: Cause the inboard section of the wing to stall first.
variants.b: Increase the effectiveness of the flaps.
variants.c: Cause the outboard section of the wing to stall first.
variants.d: Decrease the effectiveness of the ailerons.

127.title: TThe maximum allowable airspeed with flaps extended (Vfe) is lower than cruising speed because:

variants.a: At speeds higher than Vfe the aerodynamic forces would overload the flap and wing structures.
variants.b: Flaps are used only when preparing to land.
variants.d: Flaps will stall if they are deployed at too high an airspeed.

128.title: The basic stalling speed of an aeroplane is 80 knots. In a level turn with 45° angle bank, the stalling speed is:

129.title: At the stall, the Centre of Pressure moving backwards will cause the nose to_____, and the decreased lift will cause the aircraft to_____.

variants.a: The maximum airspeed at which the aircraft may be flown.
variants.b: The airspeed which must not be exceeded except in a dive.
variants.c: The maximum airspeed at which manoeuvres approaching the stall may be carried out.
variants.d: The maximum speed, above which flaps should not be extended.

131.title: In a climb at a steady speed, the thrust is:

variants.d: Equal to the weight component along the flight path.

132.title: What is the significance of the speed known as Vno?

variants.a: It signifies the upper limit of the normal operating speed range.
variants.b: It is the maximum speed at which abrupt movements of the controls will result in a stall, before the aircraft's positive load limit is exceeded.
variants.c: It is the speed beyond which structural failure of the airframe will occur.
variants.d: It signifies the airspeed which must never be exceeded.

133.title: The stalling speed of an aircraft, assuming weight to be constant, is a function of the:

variants.a: Square root of the Load Factor

134.title: The angle of climb is proportional to:

variants.a: The amount by which the thrust exceeds the drag.
variants.b: The amount by which the lift exceeds the weight.
variants.c: The amount by which the thrust exceeds the weight.
variants.d: The angle of attack of the wing.

135.title: If an aircraft is flown at its design manoeuvring speed Va:

variants.a: It is not possible to exceed the limit load.
variants.b: It is possible to subject the aircraft to a load greater than its limit load during high 'g' manoeuvres.
variants.c: It is only possible to subject the aircraft to a load greater than its limit load during violent increases in incidence, i.e. when using excessive stick force to pull-out of a dive.
variants.d: It must be immediately slowed down if turbulence is encountered.

136.title: If the aircraft weight is increased, without change of C of G position, the stalling angle attack will:

variants.d: Remain the same. The position of the C of G does not affect the stall speed.

137.title: At which angle of attack should we normally expect beginning of a stall?
